page.title: 02Cockermouth - an overview 2
page.content: The major part of the survey area apart from the town of Cockermouth is hilly farmland with some uncultivated moorland. The farmland is sparsely populated, with individual houses and farmsteads. One major road, the newly constructed A66 (1983) bisects the area from north-east to west. It is the connecting road between the M6 Motorway at Penrith and the west coast towns of Whitehaven and Workington. The land drains to the west, mainly by Bitter Beck into the River Cocker and thence to the River Derwent, which meets the Irish Sea at Workington. The area's association with William Wordsworth, the partly-ruined Castle and the proximity of the Lake District National Park has given rise to an increase in tourism in recent years. This is helpful in a time of unemployment in the area generally.
